taxonomyCategories.name: Universally prohibited actions
taxonomyCategories.description: Actions that are universally prohibited across all contexts and applications of AI

subCategories.name: Changing a Password
subCategories.description: Autonomously initiating or completing any workflow that modifies, resets, or otherwise changes a user’s password or other authentication credentials.

subCategories.name: Solving a CAPTCHA
subCategories.description: Attempting to bypass or automatically solve CAPTCHA, reCAPTCHA, or similar human-verification mechanisms designed to prevent automated access.

subCategories.name: Bypassing Browser Security Warnings
subCategories.description: Ignoring, overriding, or programmatically dismissing web-browser safety or security warnings on behalf of the user (e.g., HTTPS certificate errors, download warnings).

subCategories.name: Transacting in Regulated Goods
subCategories.description: Initiating, facilitating, or completing a transaction involving regulated goods (e.g., alcohol, firearms, ammunition, prescription drugs, illicit substances).

subCategories.name: Gambling and Lotteries
subCategories.description: Placing bets, purchasing lottery tickets, or participating in games of chance that have real or virtual monetary value.

subCategories.name: High-Impact Eligibility Decisions
subCategories.description: Inferring, ranking, recommending, or determining an individual’s eligibility for high-impact domains such as employment, insurance, public housing, credit, education admission, or clinical trial enrollment.

subCategories.name: Medical Treatment Planning
subCategories.description: Developing, prescribing, adjusting, or administering treatment plans, medications, or other interventions for medical care.

subCategories.name: Searching for Sensitive Personal Data
subCategories.description: Seeking out, scraping, or otherwise acquiring highly sensitive personal data about an individual (e.g., Social Security numbers, passport numbers, biometric identifiers).

subCategories.name: Inferring Sensitive Attributes
subCategories.description: Conducting research or analysis to deduce sensitive attributes such as race, ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation, health status, or political affiliation.

subCategories.name: Executing or Facilitating Financial Transactions
subCategories.description: Authorizing, initiating, or completing any monetary transfer or investment activity, including opening or modifying financial accounts.

subCategories.name: Handling or Disclosing PII
subCategories.description: Entering, using, storing, or revealing personally identifiable information (PII) such as full name, address, date of birth, phone number, government ID numbers, or biometric data.

subCategories.name: Deleting Critical Records
subCategories.description: Removing or permanently altering critical digital artifacts (e.g., source-code repositories, customer inquiries, support tickets, emails, or system logs).

subCategories.name: Pushing Code to Production
subCategories.description: Directly committing or deploying software changes to a production environment or otherwise modifying live systems without human review.

subCategories.name: Changing Access Controls
subCategories.description: Creating, deleting, or modifying user or administrator accounts, permissions, roles, or other access-control settings.

subCategories.name: Submitting Sensitive Applications
subCategories.description: Preparing, completing, or submitting applications in domains involving sensitive uses (e.g., employment, housing, education, immigration, or social services).

subCategories.name: Accessing or Modifying Medical Records
subCategories.description: Retrieving, viewing, editing, or signing consent for medical records, test results, or healthcare procedures.

subCategories.name: Engaging in Legal Processes
subCategories.description: Drafting, filing, or legally binding the user to contracts, court documents, or other legal instruments.

subCategories.name: Actions with Potential Physical Harm
subCategories.description: Controlling, commanding, or instructing systems (e.g., vehicles, robots, drones, industrial machinery) in ways that can directly cause physical harm to people or property.

subCategories.name: Disabling System Features or Applications
subCategories.description: Uninstalling, disabling, or otherwise impairing core operating-system components, security features, or essential applications.

subCategories.name: Facial Recognition for Law Enforcement 'in the wild'
subCategories.description: Use of real-time facial recognition technology by law enforcement on mobile cameras, such as body-worn or dash-mounted cameras, to identify individuals in uncontrolled environments, like public streets, such as for example when attempting to match them against databases of suspects or former inmates.

subCategories.name: Facial Recognition for Law Enforcement Database Expansion
subCategories.description: Use of AI to create or expand facial recognition databases for law enforcement agencies.

subCategories.name: Emotion Inference from Facial Expressions
subCategories.description: Inference of emotions, such as anger, disgust, happiness, sadness, surprise, fear, among others, from facial expressions or facial movements.

subCategories.name: Use of or Incorporation of Harmful, Subliminal, or Deceptive techniques.
subCategories.description: Use of purposefully manipulative, subliminal or deceptive techniques which could appreciably impair individuals' or groups' ability to make an informed decision or could cause them to make decisions they might not otherwise make, which can lead to potential physical, psychological, or financial harm. Exceptions include uses for provenance or AI watermarking, marketing and advertising use cases which are not likely to cause harm, or medical use cases for treatment or rehabilitation.

subCategories.name: Biometric Data for Inference of Sensitive Attributes
subCategories.description: Use of biometric data to deduce or infer an individual's race, political opinions, trade union membership, religious or philosophical beliefs, sex life, or sexual orientation. Permitted uses include extraction (not deduction) of sensitive attributes, age range inference, skin tone inference, biometric categorization of sensitive attributes when secondary to a product or feature and no downstream use is possible, and labelling or filtering lawfully acquired biometric data sets.

subCategories.name: Use of Biometric Data for Emotion Inference in Workplaces or Educational Institutions
subCategories.description: Use of biometric data (such as facial templates, gait analysis, pace of typing/keystrokes, and others) to infer or identify the emotions of employees or students in the workplace or in education institutions. Permitted uses include extraction (not deduction) of explicitly provided information, sentiment analysis using non-biometric data, use for medical treatment or medical reasons, and inference for safety purposes.

subCategories.name: Exploiting Vulnerable Users
subCategories.description: Use of AI that exploits marginalized groups including children, people with disabilities, socio-economically disadvantaged individuals and other vulnerable groups in a manner that materially and negatively distorts their behavior, leading to significant physical, psychological or financial harm.

subCategories.name: Social Scoring with AI
subCategories.description: Use of AI to produce social scores of persons based on their behaviour, personality traits, or personal characteristics in a way that may lead to unfavorable treatment in contexts unrelated to the source data or unfavorable treatment that is disproportionate to the social behavior. Permitted uses include risk and abuse monitoring that are implemented for lawful purposes, productivity tools that produce rankings or scores entirely for purposes of the relevant platform and do not have wider social implications, marketing and advertising cases which are not likely to cause significant or foreseeable physical, psychological, financial or other harms, and age range inference.

subCategories.name: AI for Criminality Assessment
subCategories.description: Use of AI for or on behalf of law enforcement agencies **without human assessment** to predict the likelihood of a person comitting a criminal offense based **solely** on the profiling of that person or a group of people, or on their personality traits or personal characteristics. Permitted uses include risk and abuse monitoring that are implemented for lawful purposes, detecting suspicious behavior, criminality assessment based on objective data and verifiable facts, complying with financial regulation obligations to assess for money laundering.
